dc:source.dc:abstract: The genetic diversity of loci and mutations underlying hereditary hearing loss is an active area of investigation. To identify loci associated with predominantly non-syndromic sensorineural hearing loss, we performed exome sequencing of families and of single probands, as well as copy number variation (CNV) mapping in a case-control cohort.
dc:source.dc:creator: Haraksingh RR
dc:source.dc:title: Exome sequencing and genome-wide copy number variant mapping reveal novel associations with sensorineural hereditary hearing loss.

evidence.dc:description: This proband carries a heterozygous p.Met6159Val variant in ADGRV1 and a heterozygous p.Gly4Asp variant in GJB2. The p.M6159V variant is present in 13% of African alleles and 288 homozygotes in gnomAD and therefore is not scorable.

evidence.previousTestingDescription: inclusion criteria: patients' parents have normal hearing, patients are of Western-European ethnicity, patients have been seen by an experienced clinical geneticist or an otolaryngologist with clinical genetics training to exclude syndromic HL, patients show NSHL mild to profound and symmetric, GJB2 has been excluded

dc:source.dc:abstract: Although there are nearly 100 different causative genes identified for nonsyndromic hearing loss (NSHL), Sanger sequencing-based DNA diagnostics usually only analyses three, namely, GJB2, SLC26A4, and OTOF. As this is seen as inadequate, there is a need for high-throughput diagnostic methods to detect disease-causing variations, including single-nucleotide variations (SNVs), insertions/deletions (Indels), and copy-number variations (CNVs). In this study, a targeted resequencing panel for hearing loss was developed including 79 genes for NSHL and selected forms of syndromic hearing loss. One-hundred thirty one presumed autosomal-recessive NSHL (arNSHL) patients of Western-European ethnicity were analyzed for SNVs, Indels, and CNVs. In addition, we established a straightforward variant classification system to deal with the large number of variants encountered. We estimate that combining prescreening of GJB2 with our panel leads to a diagnosis in 25%-30% of patients. Our data show that after GJB2, the most commonly mutated genes in a Western-European population are TMC1, MYO15A, and MYO7A (3.1%). CNV analysis resulted in the identification of causative variants in two patients in OTOA and STRC. One of the major challenges for diagnostic gene panels is assigning pathogenicity for variants. A collaborative database collecting all identified variants from multiple centers could be a valuable resource for hearing loss diagnostics.
dc:source.dc:creator: Sommen M
dc:source.dc:title: DNA Diagnostics of Hereditary Hearing Loss: A Targeted Resequencing Approach Combined with a Mutation Classification System.

evidence.dc:description: The p.Gly1148Asp variant is present in 317/125202 (0.25%) of European (non-Finnish) alleles in gnomAD, which is too high of a frequency to consider the variant as pathogenic. The p.Gly6122Arg variant is absent from gnomAD. Not scored.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Countries with culturally accepted consanguinity provide a unique resource for the study of rare recessively inherited genetic diseases. Although hereditary hearing loss (HHL) is not uncommon, it is genetically heterogeneous, with over 85 genes causally implicated in non-syndromic hearing loss (NSHL). This heterogeneity makes many gene-specific types of NSHL exceedingly rare. We sought to define the spectrum of autosomal recessive HHL in Iran by investigating both common and rarely diagnosed deafness-causing genes.
dc:source.dc:creator: Sloan-Heggen CM
dc:source.dc:title: Characterising the spectrum of autosomal recessive hereditary hearing loss in Iran.

evidence.dc:description: p.Leu2722Ter variant is absent from gnomAD, however the individual is below the age of onset of retinitis pigmentosa in Usher Type 2 and therefore Usher syndrome cannot be ruled out in this proband.

evidence.detectionMethod: no GJB2, SLC26A4 and MT-RNR1 variants
evidence.previousTestingDescription: patients had a comprehensive auditory examination, tympanometry, PTA, ABR, and in some cases CT of inner ear. Physical and neurological examination was performed "with special attention to renal, electrocardiac and ophthalmologic differences to exclude those with syndromic deafness"

dc:source.dc:abstract: Although over 60 non-syndromic deafness genes have been identified to date, the etiologic contribution of most deafness genes remained elusive. In this study, we addressed this issue by targeted next-generation sequencing of a large cohort of non-syndromic deaf probands.
dc:source.dc:creator: Yang T
dc:source.dc:title: Genetic etiology study of the non-syndromic deafness in Chinese Hans by targeted next-generation sequencing.

evidence.rdfs:label: C5

evidence.dc:description: Both variants in this proband are absent from gnomAD. No detailed age information or clinical information is provided for this patient. There is not enough information to rule out a later onset of retinitis pigmentosa in this proband and therefore Usher syndrome. This proband is not scored.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Autosomal recessive nonsyndromic deafness (ARNSD) is characterized by a high degree of genetic heterogeneity, with reported mutations in 58 different genes. This study was designed to detect deafness-causing variants in a multiethnic cohort with ARNSD by using whole-exome sequencing (WES).
dc:source.dc:creator: Bademci G
dc:source.dc:title: Comprehensive analysis via exome sequencing uncovers genetic etiology in autosomal recessive nonsyndromic deafness in a large multiethnic cohort.

evidence.dc:description: The p.K986Ter variant is absent from gnomAD, however this proband is not scored because the individual and the affected sibling are below the age of retinitis pigmentosa onset in Usher syndrome type 2, and therefore Usher syndrome cannot be ruled out.

Variant is absent from gnomAD. This case is not scored because the proband is below the age of onset of retinitis pigmentosa in Usher syndrome type 2, and therefore Usher syndrome cannot be ruled out.

evidence.previousTestingDescription: ophthalmologic examination including electroretinogrphy and optical coherence tomography was performed to rule out retinal abnormalities

dc:source.dc:abstract: This study was designed to delineate genetic contributions, if any, to sporadic forms of mild to moderate sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) not related to GJB2 mutations (DFNB1) in a pediatric population.
dc:source.dc:creator: Kim NK
dc:source.dc:title: Whole-exome sequencing reveals diverse modes of inheritance in sporadic mild to moderate sensorineural hearing loss in a pediatric population.

evidence.rdfs:label: SB112-204

evidence.dc:description: Claim of digenic inheritance of c.3022+2T>G ADGRV1 variant and p.Ser26LeufsX53 PDZD7 variant. No evidence of digenic inheritance as disease mechanism.

evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted genomic enrichment and massively parallel sequencing

dc:source.dc:abstract: Non-syndromic hearing loss (NSHL) is the most common sensory impairment in humans. Until recently its extreme genetic heterogeneity precluded comprehensive genetic testing. Using a platform that couples targeted genomic enrichment (TGE) and massively parallel sequencing (MPS) to sequence all exons of all genes implicated in NSHL, we tested 100 persons with presumed genetic NSHL and in so doing established sequencing requirements for maximum sensitivity and defined MPS quality score metrics that obviate Sanger validation of variants.
dc:source.dc:creator: Shearer AE
dc:source.dc:title: Advancing genetic testing for deafness with genomic technology.

evidence.rdfs:label: Sample ID 39

evidence.dc:description: The reported variants, p.Arg4062Gln and p.Ile5643AsnfsX20, are present in 1/111476 and 2/105636 European (Non-Finnish) alleles in gnomAD, respectively. This individual is below the age of retinitis pigmentosa onset, and therefore there is not enough information to score this individual as a nonsyndromic HL case.

dc:source.dc:abstract: In the present work, we identified two novel compound heterozygote mutations in the GPR98 (G protein-coupled receptor 98) gene causing Usher syndrome. Whole-exome sequencing was performed to study the genetic causes of Usher syndrome in a Moroccan family with three affected siblings. We identify two novel compound heterozygote mutations (c.1054C > A, c.16544delT) in the GPR98 gene in the three affected siblings carrying post-linguale bilateral moderate hearing loss with normal vestibular functions and before installing visual disturbances. This is the first time that mutations in the GPR98 gene are described in the Moroccan deaf patients.
dc:source.dc:creator: Bousfiha A
dc:source.dc:title: Novel compound heterozygous mutations in the GPR98 (USH2C) gene identified by whole exome sequencing in a Moroccan deaf family.

evidence.dc:description: The p.Pro352Thr variant is present in 6/112900 European (non-FInnish) alleles in gnomAD. The p.Leu5515Ter variant is absent from gnomAD. While the proband and a 16 year old female sibling are around the age of onset of retinitis pigmentosa in ADGRV1-associated Usher syndrome type 2, the affects carry a missense and a nonsense. These variants are not inconsistent with the mechanism of disease in ADGRV1-associated Usher syndrome type 2 patients, therefore there is not enough evidence to score this family as nonsyndromic HL.

evidence.detectionMethod: 131 HL genes screened. GJB2, SLC26A4 and MT-RNR1 ruled out

dc:source.dc:abstract: The genetic heterogeneity of non-syndromic hearing loss (NSHL) has hampered the identification of its pathogenic mutations. Several recent studies applied targeted genome enrichment (TGE) and massively parallel sequencing (MPS) to simultaneously screen a large set of known hearing loss (HL) genes. However, most of these studies were focused on familial cases. To evaluate the effectiveness of TGE and MPS on screening sporadic NSHL patients, we recruited 63 unrelated sporadic NSHL probands, who had various levels of HL and were excluded for mutations in GJB2, MT-RNR1, and SLC26A4 genes. TGE and MPS were performed on 131 known HL genes using the Human Deafness Panel oto-DA3 (Otogenetics Corporation., Norcross, GA). We identified 14 pathogenic variants in STRC, CATSPER2, USH2A, TRIOBP, MYO15A, GPR98, and TMPRSS3 genes in eight patients (diagnostic rate = 12.7%). Among these variants, 10 were novel compound heterozygous mutations. The identification of pathogenic mutations could predict the progression of HL, and guide diagnosis and treatment of the disease.
dc:source.dc:creator: Gu X
dc:source.dc:title: Genetic testing for sporadic hearing loss using targeted massively parallel sequencing identifies 10 novel mutations.

evidence.rdfs:label: G567

evidence.dc:description: The p.Arg3405Ter and p.Arg4789Gln variants are present in 1/30732 and 1/30756 South Asian alleles in gnomAD, respectively. No age information is available for this proband, and no proof of clinical examination has ruled out a possible later onset of retinitis pigmentosa. Therefore, Usher syndrome cannot be ruled out and this case is not scored.

dc:source.dc:abstract: PurposeHearing loss is more prevalent in the Saudi Arabian population than in other populations; however, the full range of genetic etiologies in this population is unknown. We report the genetic findings from 33 Saudi hearing-loss probands of tribal ancestry, with predominantly prelingual severe to profound hearing loss.MethodsTesting was performed over the course of 2012-2016, and involved initial GJB2 sequence and GJB6-D13S1830 deletion screening, with negative cases being reflexed to a next-generation sequencing panel with 70, 71, or 87 hearing-loss genes.ResultsA "positive" result was reached in 63% of probands, with two recurrent OTOF variants (p.Glu57* and p.Arg1792His) accountable for a third of all "positive" cases. The next most common cause was pathogenic variants in MYO7A and SLC26A4, each responsible for three "positive" cases. Interestingly, only one "positive" diagnosis had a DFNB1-related cause, due to a homozygous GJB6-D13S1830 deletion, and no sequence variants in GJB2 were detected.ConclusionOur findings implicate OTOF as a potential major contributor to hearing loss in the Saudi population, while highlighting the low contribution of GJB2, thus offering important considerations for clinical testing strategies for Saudi patients. Further screening of Saudi patients is needed to characterize the genetic spectrum in this population.
dc:source.dc:creator: Almontashiri NAM
dc:source.dc:title: Recurrent variants in OTOF are significant contributors to prelingual nonsydromic hearing loss in Saudi patients.

evidence.dc:description: The p.Asn142Ser variant is absent from gnomAD. This proband is not scored due to lack of ERG and due to "inconclusive" result of authors.

evidence.previousTestingDescription: inclusion criteria: patients' parents have normal hearing, patients are of Western-European ethnicity, patients have been seen by an experienced clinical geneticist or an otolaryngologist with clinical genetics training to exclude syndromic HL, patients show NSHL mild to profound and symmetric, GJB2 has been excluded

evidence.dc:description: The p.Ser955Ter variant is present in 1/29158 South Asian alleles in gnomAD, and the p.Asp1301GlufsX24 variant is absent from gnomAD. There is no age information or specific phenotypic and clinical information available for this proband. Additionally, this proband carries a LOF variant on both alleles, which is the same mechanism of disease of ADGRV1-associated Usher syndrome type 2. Therefore, there is not enough information to rule out Usher syndrome in this patient. Not scored.

evidence.detectionMethod: 131 HL gene panel. GJB2, SLC26A4 and MT-RNR1 ruled out
evidence.rdfs:label: J540

evidence.dc:description: The p.D321Y variant is present in 12/17246 East Asian alleles in gnomAD. The p.E3143D variant is absent from gnomAD. This proband is not scored because the age of onset of hearing loss is inconsistent with other reports of hearing loss onset.

evidence.detectionMethod: GJB2 variants have been ruled out

dc:source.dc:abstract: The advent of massive parallel sequencing is rapidly changing the strategies employed for the genetic diagnosis and research of rare diseases that involve a large number of genes. So far it is not clear whether these approaches perform significantly better than conventional single gene testing as requested by clinicians. The current yield of this traditional diagnostic approach depends on a complex of factors that include gene-specific phenotype traits, and the relative frequency of the involvement of specific genes. To gauge the impact of the paradigm shift that is occurring in molecular diagnostics, we assessed traditional Sanger-based sequencing (in 2011) and exome sequencing followed by targeted bioinformatics analysis (in 2012) for five different conditions that are highly heterogeneous, and for which our center provides molecular diagnosis. We find that exome sequencing has a much higher diagnostic yield than Sanger sequencing for deafness, blindness, mitochondrial disease, and movement disorders. For microsatellite-stable colorectal cancer, this was low under both strategies. Even if all genes that could have been ordered by physicians had been tested, the larger number of genes captured by the exome would still have led to a clearly superior diagnostic yield at a fraction of the cost.
dc:source.dc:creator: Neveling K
dc:source.dc:title: A post-hoc comparison of the utility of sanger sequencing and exome sequencing for the diagnosis of heterogeneous diseases.

evidence.dc:description: The p.Arg2959Ter variant is present in 2/150202 European (non-Finnish) alleles in gnomAD. The c.13893+1G>A variant is absent from gnomAD. No specific age, phenotype, or clinical examination information is available for this proband. Additionally, the proband carries a LOF variant on both alleles, which is consistent with the mechanism of disease in ADGRV1-associated Usher syndrome type 2. Therefore, there is not enough information to rule out Usher syndrome in this proband.

evidence.dc:description: The p.Arg800Gln and p.Val3363AspfsX11 variants are present in 3/30182 South Asian alleles and 4/111316 European (non-Finnish) alleles in gnomAD respectively. There is not enough phenotypic information, clinical information, or age information in order to rule out a later onset of retinitis pigmentosa in this proband. Therefore, Usher syndrome type 2 cannot be ruled out and this proband is not scored.

dc:description:
ADGRV1, previously known as GPR98, was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive nonsyndromic hearing loss in 2013 (Yang et al., 23767834). At least 27 unique variants (missense, nonsense, frameshift, splice-site) have been reported in humans. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 17 probands in 11 publications (23804846, 24123792, 23767834, 25528277, 25719458, 24853665, 29048421, 26226137, 26445815, 27068579, 28951997). Evidence disputing this gene-disease relationship includes lack of age information, lack of clinical examination history, and high allele frequency of variants in population databases. Of note, this gene has also been implicated in Usher syndrome Type 2. This has been assessed separately as Definitive. The mechanism of disease of ADGRV1-Usher syndrome Type 2 is homozygous loss of function, which is consistent with the variants reported in ADGRV1-nonsyndomic hearing loss patients. In summary, there is convincing evidence disputing the relationship between ADGRV1 and autosomal recessive nonsyndromic hearing loss. More evidence is needed to either support or refute the role ADGRV1 plays in this disease. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Hearing Loss Working Group on 3/19/19 (SOP Version 6).
Evidence disputing this gene-disease relationship includes lack of age information, lack of clinical examination history, and high allele frequency of variants in population databases. Of note, this gene has also been implicated in Usher syndrome Type 2. This has been assessed separately as Definitive. The mechanism of disease of ADGRV1-Usher syndrome Type 2 is homozygous loss of function, which is consistent with the variants reported in ADGRV1-nonsyndomic hearing loss patients.
